central_thesis: This text provides a foundational glossary for a specific Kabbalistic system, meticulously defining key terms related to the process of divine emanation, the structure of spiritual realms (Olamot), and the interaction between Lights (Orot) and Vessels (Kelim), particularly within the Partzufim following the Tzimtzum. It details the metaphysical mechanics underlying creation and spiritual rectification.

structure_content.summary: Definitions clarify various forms and functions of Light: Ohr Yashar as direct emanation, Ohr Hozer as reflective light, Ohr Pnimi as indwelling light, and Ohr Makif as encompassing light. This section also introduces specific 'Lights of the Soul' such as Nefesh, Ruach, Neshama, Haya, and Yechida, detailing their sequence and corresponding vessels.

This segment explains the role of vessels (Kelim), the Masach (screen) in limiting Light, and fundamental processes like Zivug de Hakaa (striking union). Concepts such as Aviut (coarseness/desire to receive), Gevul (boundary), Gag (Keter), and Halon (window/power of Aviut) are detailed to explain the mechanics of reception and expansion within the spiritual degrees.

The definitions outline the hierarchical organization of spiritual realities, including Adam Kadmon as the first Olam, the distinctions between Sefirot of Igulim and Yosher, and the components of a Partzuf (Rosh, Guf, ZAT). Concepts like Elyon (superior) and Tachton (inferior), Pnimiut (inner) and Hitzoniut (outer), and the 'straight' (Kav) and 'circular' (Tzinor) paths of Light are expounded.

This section covers dynamic aspects of the system, such as 'Descent' (Hitabut/increasing Aviut), 'Exit' (Shinui Tzura), 'In Passing' (Ohr Over), 'Connecting' (Hishtavut Tzura), and 'Beginning of Hitpashtut' (Keter). These terms describe the changes, movements, and relationships between spiritual entities and degrees.

Definitions here describe qualitative states like 'Annulled' (complete equality), 'Utterly Distant' (complete Hofchiut Tzura), 'Slowly' (gradual extension), and 'At Once' (non-gradual descent). These terms illustrate the spiritual proximity, separation, and speed of processes within the system.

key_concepts.definition: The first Olam (World) to receive from Ein Sof, also called 'One Kav.' It expands immediately after the Tzimtzum. Its name relates to the Sefirot of Yosher (Light of Ruach/bestowal), not Igulim (Light of Nefesh/self-reception).

The Light that is not taken in by Behina Dalet, destined to fill Behina Dalet but rejected by the Masach. It is the Light that vessels use for reception post-Tzimtzum, instead of the Behina Dalet used in Ein Sof. It is the Light that extends 'From Below Upward'.

The Ohr Elyon (Upper Light) that extends from Ein Sof and is poured to the Partzufim from the Tzimtzum onward. It is poured to the Sefirot of Yosher, adhering to the rule that the giver gives in the most Av (coarsest), which is Behina Dalet. It is the Light that expands 'From Above Downward'.

The Light meant to permeate a degree but detained by a Gevul (boundary). It has two meanings: 'Distant He'arah' (illumination from afar) and 'Guaranteed He'arah' (light that will eventually permeate because it surrounds from all sides).
The Light that is clothed (contained) within the Kli (vessel).
A great will to receive; coarseness. It is the Kli for drawing the Shefa (abundance) in every Partzuf, and is called the 'Pnimiut (inner part) of the Kli'.

A force of Tzimtzum (restriction) awakened in the Ne'etzal (emanated being) towards the Ohr Elyon. It stops Light from descending to Behina Dalet, striking it and pushing it backwards. It operates only when Light comes after Tzimtzum is temporarily revoked, being a result of Tzimtzum.

The act of the Masach detaining and concealing Light from Behina Dalet, rejecting it back to its root. This act 'strikes' and 'mates' with the Light, causing the rejected Light to become a revealed Light that clothes the Ohr Yashar, enabling Ohr Ein Sof to clothe the Partzuf.

A spiritual configuration comprised of Sefirot, often described with a 'Rosh' (head/first three Sefirot) and 'Guf' (body/lower seven Sefirot, ZAT). Every vessel of reception in the Partzufim from the Tzimtzum onward expands from Ohr Hozer.

The ten divine emanations. Sefirot of Igulim are called Galgalim (wheels) where Lights become round and Aviut/Zakut cannot be distinguished. Sefirot of Yosher (straightness) are where Light descends proportionally with Aviut, allowing for clear distinctions and structure.
The purification of the Aviut in Behina Dalet. It refers to the Masach intensifying and purifying itself to match the level of desire, considered purified from its Aviut.

The 'clothing' (Hitlabshut) of the Eser Sefirot of the Rosh in the Eser Sefirot of Ohr Hozer (ascending from Malchut). Here, Lights precede vessels, and Aviut does not ascend. It signifies a connection or hovering of Ohr Yashar over these Sefirot, rather than full permeation.

The power of Aviut in the Masach, operating in the ten Sefirot of the Rosh or Igulim, along with the ascending Ohr Hozer. It describes the mechanism by which Ohr Hozer, originally rejected due to Aviut, becomes a vessel for Ohr Elyon, allowing for the reception of Light through an 'opening' or 'window' in seemingly pure vessels without Aviut.

An acronym for Nefesh, Ruach, Neshama, Haya, Yechida, the Lights in the Eser Sefirot, named from below upward (the order in which Lights enter the Partzuf), contrary to the order of the Kelim (Keter first).

From the perspective of the Light inside the Kelim de Yosher (straight vessels), they are called Kav (line/ray). The Eser Sefirot of Olam Adam Kadmon are 'one Kav', while Olam Atzilut has three Kavim.
From the perspective of their Kelim, the Eser Sefirot of Kelim de Yosher are called Tzinorot (pipes), as they extend and limit the Light like a tube bounding water.
The last Behina (discrimination) in any degree, characterized by firm and full control, similar to the 'fear of the King'. It is considered the Karka (ground) of every degree.

practical_system.description: The 'practical system' described within these definitions is fundamentally a metaphysical one, detailing the operative mechanics of the cosmos rather than explicit rituals for human practitioners. It outlines how divine Light (Ohr) emanates and is received by spiritual vessels (Kelim) across various degrees (Partzufim and Olamot). The core mechanism involves the interaction of Ohr Yashar (direct light) and Ohr Hozer (returning light), mediated by the Masach (screen) and the Aviut (desire to receive). The system explains how creation unfolds from the Ein Sof through successive restrictions (Tzimtzum) and unions (Zivug de Hakaa) to form distinct spiritual realities. Understanding this system provides the theoretical basis for a Kabbalist's inner work (e.g., meditations on the Sefirot, visualizations of Light-Vessel interactions, and practices aimed at achieving Hishtavut Tzura—equivalence of form with the Creator), enabling them to align their consciousness and actions with the cosmic process of Tikkun. The 'magic' here lies in the precise, inherent functioning of divine causality and effect rather than human-initiated ceremonial actions described in grimoires.

relevant_quotes.text: Ohr Hozer is the Light that is not taken in by Behina Dalet. It is the Light that is destined to fill Behina Dalet, which she still refuses to accept because of the Masach that stops it and pushes it backwards. This act is called Zivug de Hakaa.

Ohr Makif is the Light that is meant to permeate the degree, but is detained because of some Gevul in it. That name has two meanings: The 1st. Distant He'arah. The 2nd. Guaranteed He'arah, meaning a He'arah that is guaranteed to finally permeate it, because the Ohr surrounds it from all sides, giving her no escape route, until it is capable of receiving all of it.

The act of the Masach, which detains and conceals the Light from Behina Dalet and rejects the Light that belongs to her back to its root, is called Zivug de Hakaa. The name indicates that this act contains within it two opposites: on the one hand, it “strikes” the Light, meaning rejects and conceals its Heʼarah; on the other hand it "mates” with the Light, meaning it makes it reproduce and multiplies it commodiously.

The Aviut in the Partzuf that comes from the desire of Behina Dalet is called the Homer of the Partzuf. This name is borrowed from a fictitious corporeal substance that consists of the three dimensions: length, width and depth, and the six directions: up and down, east, west, north and south.

This force is called Halon, because when the Ohr Hozer and Ohr Yashar enter in order to illuminate the pure Kelim de Igulim, which do not have even a trace of Aviut, the force of Aviut in the Ohr Hozer is much lower than them. For that reason it lowers and lessens the walls of the Kelim de Igulim as it permeates them. It is like a hole in a room: although it is a hole in the wall of the room, it is also an entrance to the light of the sun.

critical_analysis.relevance: This glossary is highly relevant for serious students of Lurianic Kabbalah or similar traditions emphasizing the precise mechanics of divine emanation and the process of Tikkun (correction). It provides the technical vocabulary necessary to understand complex Kabbalistic texts that describe the formation of spiritual worlds (Olamot), the structure of divine attributes (Sefirot), and the interaction of Lights and Vessels within the Partzufim. It contextualizes fundamental concepts like Tzimtzum and Zivug de Hakaa not as abstract ideas but as operative principles governing spiritual reality. The detailed explanations, often drawing analogies to physical phenomena (like length, corporeal substances, or light entering a room), aim to make highly abstract spiritual concepts comprehensible within a systematic framework. It's a key to unlocking deeper textual study rather than a standalone philosophical treatise or practical guide.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience consists of advanced students, scholars, and practitioners of Kabbalah who are already familiar with basic Kabbalistic concepts and are seeking a deeper, more technical understanding of a specific system (likely that of Rabbi Yehuda Ashlag, given the style and specific terms). It is intended for those who need a precise lexicon to navigate complex Lurianic texts and their commentaries, rather than for beginners or those interested in general occultism without a specific focus on Kabbalistic metaphysics.
